items.title: Extinguishing the saturation horizon
Antarctic glacier retreats at record rate due to rapid flotation and calving process
Influence of three tropical oceans on western North Pacific anticyclone strengthening under global warming
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 03 November 2025

Influence of three tropical oceans on western North Pacific anticyclone strengthening under global warming
                    Zhiyuan Lu1,2 & Chunzai Wang1,3,4

npj Climate and Atmospheric Science

volume 8, Article number: 349 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Atmospheric scienceClimate changeOcean sciences

AbstractThe western North Pacific anomalous anticyclone (WNPAC) is a key atmospheric circulation system that significantly influences East Asian climate variability. Its formation and persistence result from complex interactions among the Pacific, Indian, and Atlantic Oceans. Using the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) simulations, this study examines projected changes in WNPAC under anthropogenic warming and quantifies the seasonal contributions from the three tropical oceans. The results show a clear intensification of WNPAC in winter, spring, and summer, primarily driven by enhanced Atlantic and Pacific forcing. The Atlantic’s influence intensifies through enhanced equatorial wave activity and the development of quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains, most prominent in winter and spring. During summer, equatorial Rossby wave mechanisms dominate. The Pacific’s strongest influence emerges in summer, linked to intensified easterly winds over the western Pacific, associated with enhanced sea surface temperature gradients between the Indo-Pacific warm pool and the central-western Pacific. The Indian Ocean shows comparatively weaker changes across all seasons. These findings provide a quantitative assessment of the evolving three-ocean influence on WNPAC and underscore the increasing roles of Atlantic and Pacific variability in shaping East Asian climate under future greenhouse gas emissions.

IntroductionThe western North Pacific anomalous anticyclone (WNPAC), a prominent interannual atmospheric anomaly closely associated with the El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events, plays a critical role in modulating the East Asian monsoon and climate1,2,3,4,5. Its development substantially modifies regional precipitation and drought regimes, leading to profound socioeconomic consequences across East Asia. For instance, in winter, WNPAC weakens the East Asian winter monsoon, thereby enhancing precipitation in southeastern China5,6. In summer, it typically induces enhanced rainfall over the middle-lower reaches of the Yangtze River valley while simultaneously causing extreme hot conditions in southeastern China1,7,8,9. Therefore, gaining a comprehensive understanding of the evolution and underlying maintenance mechanisms of WNPAC is essential for improving future projections of East Asian weather and climate variability.The development of WNPAC typically initiates in the boreal late fall of the El Niño mature year, reaches its peak during the subsequent winter, and may persist into the boreal summer of the El Niño decaying year2,10,11. WNPAC exhibits relatively weak intensity in fall (Supplementary Fig. 1a) compared to the other three seasons (Supplementary Fig. 1b–d). Consequently, winter, spring, and summer—recognized as the key seasons for WNPAC activity—have been extensively examined in previous studies12,13,14 and are also a focus of this study. Meanwhile, the formation and maintenance of WNPAC are primarily governed by coupled ocean-atmosphere interactions, which are strongly modulated by the collective influence of the three tropical oceans3,4,10,15,16,17,18.The maintenance mechanisms of WNPAC exhibit pronounced seasonal variability, each dominated by distinct oceanic influences3,4,12,19. Its formation in autumn and persistence into the subsequent spring are primarily driven by the El Niño-related central Eastern Pacific (CEP) sea surface temperature anomalies (SSTAs)10,14. CEP warming gives rise to several key mechanisms, including the Wind–Evaporation–SST (WES) positive feedback10,20, anomalous moist enthalpy advection11,14, and oceanic Rossby waves3,4. These mechanisms jointly result in locally suppressed convection in the western North Pacific (WNP), which, in turn, induces WNPAC. The contributions of the Indian and Atlantic Oceans emerge in the El Niño decaying spring and become more pronounced in summer. A stationary equivalent barotropic Rossby wave train, triggered by the tropical Northern Atlantic (TNA) warming, propagates toward the WNP, thereby maintaining WNPAC in the spring21. During the decaying summer, the Indian Ocean capacitor effect generates Kelvin waves17,22,23 and enhances the Indian Ocean (IO)—the western Pacific (WP) SST gradient7,24,25. These two processes together induce anomalous easterlies and anticyclonic vorticity through the Ekman pumping mechanism. Concurrently, TNA influences WNPAC by triggering multiple atmospheric responses, including an equatorial Kelvin wave that stretches from the western Indian Ocean to the western Pacific26,27, an equatorial Rossby wave28,29, and an anomalous zonally overturning circulation26,30,31. Meanwhile, the central Pacific cooling in the decaying summer, caused by ENSO phase transition, intensifies WNPAC by descending Rossby waves7,24,32. Additionally, a near-annual ENSO combination mode (C-mode), which demonstrates nonlinear interactions between ENSO and the Pacific warm pool annual cycle, further contributes to WNPAC13,33,34. As the mechanisms governing WNPAC vary seasonally, it is important to assess how they respond to global warming, which is essential for improving projections of the East Asian climate under future scenarios.With the substantial increase in anthropogenic emissions, notable changes have also been observed in WNPAC. Previous studies, based on Phase 5 of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5), have suggested a weakening trend in the summer WNPAC under a warming climate35,36. This weakening has been attributed to the diminished sensitivity of convection anomalies over the tropical Indian Ocean (TIO) and the weakened SST gradient between TIO and the western Pacific. Meanwhile, Wu et al.37 categorized CMIP5 models into two groups: one indicating a strengthening of the summer WNPAC and the other depicting its weakening. It was found that the enhancement of WNPAC was associated with a faster decay of El Niño events. The latest CMIP6 models have demonstrated overall improvements in model physics and the simulation of climate extremes38,39. Based on CMIP6 models, He et al.40 projected a strengthening of the summer WNPAC in future climate scenarios, attributing this trend to the increasing SST gradient between the TIO and the western Pacific. Additionally, Wang et al.41 pointed out that ENSO-independent summer WNPAC is projected to intensify due to enhanced precipitation-circulation feedback driven by increased atmospheric moisture.The aforementioned studies have projected future trends in WNPAC and elucidated the underlying mechanisms responsible for these changes. However, prior analyses—largely reliant on CMIP5 models—have predominantly focused on the summer season and isolated roles of the Indian or Pacific Oceans, without considering the integrated roles of all three tropical oceans or assessing the relative importance of each ocean. This limitation highlights the need for a systematic and quantitative assessment of multi-ocean contributions using the more advanced CMIP6 models. This study offers a comprehensive, seasonally detailed, and quantitative evaluation of how the Pacific, Atlantic, and Indian Oceans each contribute to trends in WNPAC under global warming, based on the latest CMIP6 climate models. This integrated approach enables a more comprehensive understanding of inter-basin dynamics and their projected changes. To ensure the reliability of our findings, we first evaluate CMIP6 models’ ability to simulate the observed WNPAC. The models reproduce realistic WNPAC-related circulation and SST patterns across seasons, and most models show consistent positive regression between the WNPAC index and DJF Niño3.4 SST (Supplementary Fig. 2), supporting their suitability for assessing future changes.ResultsEnhanced WNPAC and tropical ocean roles in a warming climateThe projected trend of WNPAC under global warming is assessed using CMIP6 model simulations spanning the period from 1900 to 2099. To quantify changes in variability, a 31-year moving standard deviation of the WNPAC index is calculated for each model. The multi-model ensemble mean (MME) reveals statistically significant intensification trends across winter, spring, and summer under the high-emission SSP585 scenario (Fig. 1a–c), with spring exhibiting a relatively weaker increase. These intensifications are further supported by robust multi-model consensus, with 86%, 70%, and 86% of CMIP6 models projecting enhanced WNPAC variability across three seasons, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 3). Notably, the magnitude of intensification is greater under higher emissions scenarios, as evident from the steepened slope of the WNPAC index’s standard deviation in SSP585 relative to SSP245 (Fig. 1a–c and Supplementary Fig. 3).Fig. 1: The increasing trend of WNPAC and the relative contributions of the three oceans under global warming.a–c Trends of standardized WNPAC variability in (a) winter, (b) spring, and (c) summer, calculated using the 31-year running standard deviation of WNPAC index under SSP585 (purple line) and SSP245 (red line) scenarios, respectively; the color transition indicates the shift from historical to SSP585/SSP245 forcing. d–f The 31-year running mean standardized amplitude (blue line) and occurrences of WNPAC events (orange line) under the SSP585 scenario forcing. Solid lines in a–f denote the MME, shading represents one standard deviation derived from 10,000 bootstrap resampling realizations. g–i Multi-model median relative contributions of the three oceans to WNPAC variability during their most influential seasons. Red labels indicate the percentage increase in explained variance contributions to WNPAC by each ocean in future projections relative to the historical period. Thin black error bars denote the central range (30th–70th percentiles) across individual models.Full size imageTo assess whether the intensification of WNPAC variability is primarily attributed to changes in amplitude or frequency, 31-year running amplitude and frequency of the WNPAC index are calculated (Fig. 1d–f; see “Methods”). The results indicate that amplitude exhibits a consistent upward trend across all three seasons, closely aligned with the overall increase in variability. In contrast, frequency shows no significant long-term trend, displaying only prominent decadal fluctuations. These findings suggest that WNPAC intensification is mainly driven by stronger events, not more frequent occurrences.Spatially, WNPAC maintains its characteristic structure across seasons (Fig. 2), while its amplitude undergoes a notable intensification, as evidenced by strengthened SLP anomalies over the WNP region during WNPAC events (Fig. 2c, f, i). This further corroborates the projected intensification of WNPAC under warming conditions. Concurrently, SSTs in the tropical Pacific, Indian, and Atlantic Oceans show strong correlations with WNPAC occurrence, with dominant influential regions identified as the CEP for the Pacific Ocean, TIO for the Indian Ocean, and TNA for the Atlantic Ocean (Fig. 2 and Supplementary Fig. 1b–d), consistent with their established roles in modulating WNPAC through coupled air-sea feedbacks10,11,14,42. Notably, while the spatial patterns of SST anomalies remain largely unchanged, their amplified magnitudes under global warming are hypothesized to further enhance WNPAC intensity (Fig. 2c, f, i).Fig. 2: Historical and projected WNPAC and associated SST anomalies based on CMIP6 models.MME SLP (contours) and SST (shading) anomalies regressed onto WNPAC index for a–c DJF, d–f MAM, and g–i JJA. a, d, g Historical simulations (1900–2014). b, e, h SSP585 future projections (2015–2099). c, f, i MME differences (SSP585 minus historical). Hatched regions denote areas where >70% of models agree on the sign of change.Full size imageTo elucidate whether these intensified SST anomalies exert greater influence on WNPAC and to determine the dominant contributing basin, the explained variance (EV) of SST anomalies on WNPAC is quantified for each key region of three tropical oceans (CEP, TIO, and TNA; see “Methods”) (Fig. 1g–i). To ensure that EV reflects meaningful physical influence rather than coincidental correlation, we first apply the Liang–Kleeman information flow method43,44 (see “Methods”), which confirms significant causal influence from SST anomalies in all three tropical oceans on WNPAC (Supplementary Fig. 4a–c). Additionally, lead–lag correlation analyses between the principal SST modes and WNPAC index reveal that the Atlantic and Indian Oceans exert their strongest influence in the concurrent season, while the Pacific shows peak influence in the preceding winter (Supplementary Fig. 4d–f). These results justify our use of seasonally aligned SST-WNPAC pairs when calculating EV.EV results are consistent with previous CESM1 pacemaker experiment results19: the Pacific Ocean dominates WNPAC variability in winter and spring, while summer variability is jointly modulated by all three tropical oceans under both historical and SSP585 scenario forcing. This seasonal pattern of relative contributions is also evident in observational data (Supplementary Fig. 1f–h). Notably, as SST variability arises from both internal dynamics and inter-basin interactions, EV reflects the relative statistical contribution of each ocean to WNPAC variability, rather than an isolated or strictly causal influence. Under anthropogenic warming, the contributions of all three tropical oceans increase, as indicated by higher explained variances under the SSP585 scenario compared to historical simulations, albeit with clear seasonal and regional disparities. During winter, the Atlantic Ocean shows the most pronounced increase in influence, with explained variance rising from 0.092 (historical) to 0.166 (SSP585), marking an ~80% increase. Similarly, in spring, the Atlantic Ocean exhibits the highest growth rate among the three oceans, with a ~ 66% increase. In summer, both the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans exhibit substantial amplification ( ~ 90% and ~98% increases, respectively). By contrast, the Indian Ocean’s contribution remains comparatively modest throughout all seasons. These results highlight the dominant role of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans in modulating future WNPAC changes under global warming.Increased tropical Atlantic’s effect on WNPACBuilding on the aforementioned findings, our results reveal that under global warming, the TNA region shows enhanced SST anomalies during WNPAC events and exhibits the greatest amplification of influence among the three tropical oceans. These dual intensifications call for a systematic investigation into whether and how warming in the TNA region intensifies WNPAC. To address this, atmospheric responses associated with TNA warming are examined for historical experiments and SSP585 experiments, along with their differences (Fig. 3 and Supplementary Fig. 5). Given that ENSO strongly modulates global climate variability and partially influences TNA SST, its effect—represented by the winter Niño3.4 index—is linearly removed prior to regression analysis to isolate the relative independent contribution of TNA SST variability (see “Methods”). As supported by lead–lag correlations, TNA index exerts its strongest impact on WNPAC in the simultaneous season and is thus used in seasonally matched regressions (Supplementary Fig. 4d–f).Fig. 3: The Atlantic Ocean’s ENSO-independent influence on intensified WNPAC via equatorial waves.a–f MME partial regression patterns of precipitation (shading; units: mm day-1), 850 hPa horizontal wind (vector unit: m s-1), and sea level pressure (SLP; contour; units: hPa) onto TNA index, after removing ENSO effects, across a, b winter, c, d spring, and e, f summer. a, c, e Historical forcing (1900–2014). b, d, f Future changes (SSP585 minus historical; 2015–2099). Only positive SLP anomalies are represented by solid blue contours. Data are shown only in regions where more than 60% of models agree on the sign of regression. g Multi-model medians Rossby wave index, defined as the area-averaged negative precipitation anomaly over the tropical western Pacific (5°–25°N, 130°E–180°E; blue box in (a)), for historical and SSP585 projection periods. h Multi-model medians Kelvin wave index, defined as the area-averaged negative zonal wind anomaly over the equatorial western Pacific (0°–5°N, 120°E–160°E; red box in (a)).Full size imageIn historical simulations, TNA-induced WNPAC exhibits weak intensity in winter and spring but strengthens markedly in summer, as evidenced by pronounced anticyclonic wind and SLP anomalies (Fig. 3a, c, e). Under the high-emission SSP585 scenario, projections reveal the emergence of WNPAC in both winter and spring (Supplementary Fig. 5a, b), and a notable intensification across all three seasons, with significantly strengthened SLP anomalies (Fig. 3b, d, f). These results suggest that the intensification of WNPAC under global warming is strongly driven by TNA warming.To elucidate the mechanisms underlying these projected changes, the analysis first focuses on the tropical pathway through which TNA warming influences WNPAC under global warming. TNA warming excites an equatorial cyclonic Rossby wave response in the eastern North Pacific that sustains WNPAC through the WES feedback mechanism. Specifically, the northwestern branch of this cyclonic circulation strengthens northeasterly trade winds and also advects lower moist enthalpy (drier, cooler air) from high latitudes. These processes both increase surface evaporation and result in cooling over the central Pacific, which in turn further reinforces WNPAC through Rossby wave dynamics28,29,45,46. This mechanism is well represented in CMIP6 models, particularly in summer, as indicated by the westward extension of tropospheric temperature anomalies (Supplementary Fig. 5), northerly and northwesterly wind anomalies over the CEP region and negative precipitation anomalies over the central Pacific (Fig. 3c, e and Supplementary Fig. 5).In addition, TNA warming induces anomalous westerlies over the equatorial eastern Pacific, which enhances warming and precipitation in that region. This warming also strengthens the northeasterly trade winds by strengthening the cyclonic Rossby wave response. Under greenhouse warming, the Rossby wave effect is projected to intensify in both winter and summer (Fig. 3b, f), characterized by stronger positive precipitation anomalies over the equatorial eastern Pacific, significantly enhanced northwesterly winds in the central Pacific, and more pronounced negative precipitation anomalies in the central and western Pacific. In spring, these anomalies show a relatively weaker enhancement, contributing only modestly to WNPAC amplification (Fig. 3d). To quantify the Rossby wave effect under the global warming, mean precipitation anomalies over the central-western Pacific are analyzed (Fig. 3g). Results indicate that precipitation is projected to become more negative across all three seasons, particularly in winter and summer, with a notable reversal of anomalies in winter and significantly intensified drought in summer, thereby further amplifying WNPAC. While this index effectively captures tropical Rossby wave activity, it cannot fully exclude possible interference from mid-latitude wave trains, which will be further discussed later.Concurrently, the Kelvin wave process acts as another equatorial pathway through which TNA warming modulates WNPAC. TNA warming excites Kelvin waves that propagate eastward across the Indian Ocean into the western Pacific, inducing anomalous easterlies over the equatorial western Pacific (Fig. 3a, c, e) and generating WNPAC via Ekman divergence26,46,47. This eastward propagation is reflected in tropospheric temperature anomalies extending into the equatorial western Pacific (Supplementary Fig. 5). Under global warming, the Kelvin wave process is also projected to intensify in winter and spring, as indicated by enhanced anomaly easterlies over the equatorial western Pacific (Fig. 3b, d). Quantified by zonal wind anomalies (Fig. 3h), the process exhibits significant amplification during winter, while this amplified influence weakens in spring and almost dissipates in summer (Fig. 3f). This seasonal dissipation is consistent with shifts in the Walker circulation (Fig. 4). During winter and spring, enhanced ascent over the equatorial western Atlantic and intensified subsidence over the central Pacific contribute to strengthened easterlies over the western Pacific (Fig. 4b, d). However, as ENSO decays in summer, the anomaly intensified subsidence become confined to the eastern Indian Ocean (Fig. 4e) due to pre-existing warming in the equatorial western Pacific (Figs. 2g, h and 4g and Supplementary Fig. 1d). Consequently, the descending motion over the eastern Indian Ocean is further enhanced under global warming (Fig. 4f), leading to intensified cooling in that region (Fig. 4h), which in turn reduces the Indian Ocean-Western Pacific SST gradient and ultimately weakens the equatorial western Pacific easterlies.Fig. 4: Equatorial atmospheric circulation responses to TNA warming (ENSO-independent).a–f MME partial regression patterns of 0°–5°N meridional mean zonal (U; vectors; units: m s⁻¹) and vertical winds (wap; shading and vectors; units: Pa s⁻¹) onto TNA index, after removing ENSO effects, for three seasons: a, b winter, c, d spring, and e, f summer. a, c, e Historical simulations (1900–2014). b, d, f SSP585 minus historical differences (2015–2099). Data are shown only in regions where more than 60% of models agree on the sign of regression. g Partial regression of SST anomalies (°C) onto TNA index, after removing ENSO effects, under historical forcing. h SST differences (SSP585 minus historical). Hatched regions denote areas where more than 70% of models agree on the sign of change.Full size imageA third mechanism involves the excitation of quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains21. Enhanced convection anomalies over the tropical northwestern Atlantic, driven by TNA warming, excite quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains that propagate to the western North Pacific, amplifying WNPAC intensity (Fig. 5a, c, e, g and Supplementary Fig. 6). Notably, these wave trains are particularly prominent in winter and spring (Fig. 5a, c), but dissipate in summer (Fig. 5e). In the warming world, this pathway is also projected to intensify in winter and spring, featuring strengthened cyclonic and anticyclonic anomalies along the wave trajectory (Fig. 5b, d). Wave train intensity, measured by 200 hPa GPH anomalies over key circulation centers, confirms an increase during winter and spring, consistent with amplified TNA SSTAs (Fig. 5h).Fig. 5: The Atlantic Ocean’s influence on intensified WNPAC via quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains.a–f MME regression patterns of 200 hPa GPH (shading; units: m) and horizontal wave activity flux (WAF; vectors; units: m² s⁻²) onto TNA index during a,b winter, c, d spring, and e, f summer. a, c, e Historical simulations (1900–2014). b, d, f Future changes (SSP585 minus historical; 2015–2099). g Historical winter regression of GPH and horizontal winds (vectors; units: m s⁻¹). Data are shown only in regions where more than 60% of models agree on the sign of regression. h Multi-model medians of the quasi-stationary Rossby wave train index, defined as the mean 200 hPa GPH anomaly over the regions marked in (g), comparing historical and SSP585 periods.Full size imageIn summary, the Atlantic Ocean contributes to WNPAC intensification across all seasons through distinct mechanisms: strengthened equatorial waves and quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains in winter, a more pronounced quasi-stationary Rossby wave train in spring, and intensified equatorial Rossby wave dynamics in summer.Dominant role of the tropical Pacific in summer WNPAC intensificationThe tropical Pacific Ocean’s contribution to WNPAC increases significantly in summer. To assess this enhanced role under global warming, we also examine the changes of Pacific-driven WNPAC activity and identify the underlying mechanisms (Fig. 6 and Supplementary Fig. 7). The Pacific index (CEP) is defined using DJF SST anomalies to reflect the mature ENSO signal, consistent with its lagged influence on WNPAC confirmed by lead–lag correlations (Supplementary Fig. 4d–f).Fig. 6: The Pacific Ocean’s influence on intensified WNPAC.a–f MME regression patterns of precipitation (shading; units: mm day⁻¹), 850 hPa horizontal winds (vectors; units: m s⁻¹), and SLP (contours; units: hPa) onto CEP index during a, b winter, c, d spring, and e, f summer. a, c, e Historical forcing (1900–2014). b, d, f Future changes (SSP585 minus historical; 2015–2099). Data are shown only in regions where more than 60% of models agree on the sign of regression. g Multi-model medians of the Rossby wave index, defined as the area-averaged negative precipitation anomalies over the tropical western Pacific (5°–25°N, 130°E–180°E; blue box in (a)), for historical and SSP585 periods. h Multi-model medians of Easterly Wind Index, calculated as the area-averaged negative zonal wind anomaly over the western Pacific (0°–15°N, 120°E–160°E; red box in (a)).Full size imageThe ENSO-related WNPAC intensifies markedly during the decaying summer, as evidenced by significantly intensified SLP anomalies and anticyclonic wind circulation over the WNP region (Fig. 6f). In contrast, no substantial intensification rate is observed in winter and spring (Fig. 6b, d).The influence of the tropical Pacific primarily operates through two mechanisms: WES feedback triggered by El Niño10,11,14 and the Rossby wave induced by central Pacific cooling7,24,32. Under global warming, although CEP warming intensifies when WNPAC occurs in both winter and spring (Fig. 2c, f), the resultant cyclonic Rossby waves—particularly northeasterly wind anomalies over the central Pacific—remain weakly amplified (Fig. 6b, d). These weak amplified anomalies fail to significantly enhance the background trade winds or introduce negative moist enthalpy, leading to only marginal suppression of convection and minimal WNPAC intensification. Quantified via precipitation anomalies over the WNP (Fig. 6g), the Rossby wave effect shows limited enhancement in winter and spring.In contrast, during the summer of ENSO decay phases, CEP warming weakens while cooling over the central-western Pacific strengthens (Fig. 2g, h). This cooling intensifies under global warming (Fig. 2i), further suppressing convection and reinforcing WNPAC via enhanced Rossby wave activity (Fig. 6f). The quantified Rossby wave index increases by 90.7% in summer (JJA), which is notably higher than in winter (DJF, 36.5%) and spring (MAM, 24.0%), although its overall magnitude remains moderate (Fig. 6g).Simultaneously, enhanced warming over the Indo-Pacific warm pool and cooling over the central-western Pacific (CWP) establish a robust SST gradient (Fig. 2g, h), which induces easterly anomalies over the WNP region (Fig. 6e and Supplementary Fig. 7c). These easterlies maintain WNPAC via Ekman pumping-induced boundary layer divergence24,25,40. Under global warming, these easterlies strengthen notably in summer (Fig. 6f), quantified by zonal wind anomalies over the tropical western Pacific (Fig. 6h). The increase in easterly winds (Fig. 6f, h) is more significant than the enhancement in Rossby wave activity (Fig. 6f, g), suggesting that the SST gradient–induced easterlies constitute the primary mechanism behind the enhanced Pacific contribution to intensified WNPAC in summer.Consequently, the Pacific’s contribution to WNPAC intensification peaks during El Niño decay summers, driven predominantly by stronger easterlies associated with enhanced SST gradients between the Indo-Pacific warm pool and the central-western Pacific, and to a lesser extent by increased Rossby wave activity linked to central-eastern Pacific cooling.Modest tropical Indian’s effect on WNPACThe tropical Indian Ocean exhibits a comparatively limited increase in its contribution to WNPAC across all three seasons and exerts its greatest influence during the concurrent season (Supplementary Fig. 4d–f). During the decay phase of El Niño in spring and summer, TIO warming triggers anomalous easterlies over the western WNP through two primary mechanisms: equatorial eastward-propagating Kelvin waves26,27 and the Indian Ocean-Western Pacific SST gradient7,24,25. Both processes support WNPAC maintenance by suppressing convection via Ekman pumping (Supplementary Fig. 8). Projections indicate that these easterly anomalies intensify during spring and summer under global warming conditions (Fig. 7c, d), although their strength increase remains significantly weaker than the influences from the Pacific (Fig. 6h). The relatively weak WNPAC intensification associated with the Indian Ocean (Fig. 7a–c) can be attributed to limited warming over the northern Indian Ocean (Fig. 2f, i), where SST trends are neutral or even negative under global warming, and to a suppressed convective response likely caused by increased atmospheric stability under global warming35,40,48 (Fig. 7a–c).Fig. 7: The Indian Ocean’s ENSO-independent influence on intensified WNPAC.a–c Differences in MME partial regression patterns of precipitation (shading; units: mm day⁻¹), 850 hPa horizontal winds (vectors; units: m s⁻¹) and SLP (contour; units: hPa) onto the TIO index under SSP585 forcing relative to historical forcing, after removing ENSO effects, during a winter, b spring, and c summer. Data are shown only in regions where more than 60% of models agree on the sign of regression. d Multi-model medians of the Easterly Wind Index.Full size imageDiscussionOur study reveals that WNPAC intensifies across winter, spring, and summer under global warming. Building on prior studies that largely focused on summer or on individual basins, this work provides a systematic and quantitative inter-basin comparison of WNPAC across key seasons, offering an integrated framework to evaluate the relative contributions of the Pacific, Atlantic, and Indian Oceans. Through explained variance analysis with seasonally aligned assessments, we quantify both the relative importance and distinct pathways of the three tropical oceans. The results underscore the dominant roles of the Atlantic and Pacific in intensifying WNPAC under global warming, with the Atlantic exhibiting the most pronounced increase in influence and the Pacific exerting its strongest impact during summer, whereas the Indian Ocean’s contribution remains comparatively modest.To assess how these amplified oceanic contributions drive the intensification of WNPAC, we analyze the underlying mechanistic linkages (Fig. 8). The results indicate that TNA warming primarily intensifies WNPAC through equatorial wave responses and quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains during winter. In spring, the influence of equatorial waves weakens, and upper-tropospheric quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains become a dominant mechanism. During summer, the intensification is mainly attributed to equatorial Rossby wave dynamics. The Pacific Ocean contributes to summer WNPAC intensification primarily through anomalous easterlies over the WNP, induced by the enhanced SST gradient between the Indo-Pacific warm pool and the central-western Pacific. A secondary contribution arises from Rossby waves triggered by cooling in the central Pacific. In contrast, the Indian Ocean exerts a moderate and relatively consistent influence across all three seasons. Collectively, these findings highlight the seasonally distinct yet increasingly important roles of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans in modulating WNPAC intensification under future warming scenarios.Fig. 8: Schematic representation of the mechanisms contributing to intensified WNPAC.a In winter, enhanced TNA warming intensifies WNPAC through three pathways: (1) triggering westward-propagating Rossby waves that reach the WNP region, reinforcing trade winds and promoting surface cooling; (2) generating eastward-propagating Kelvin waves that reach the western Pacific; and (3) enhancing convection over the tropical North Atlantic, which excites quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains in the upper troposphere extending toward WNP. b In spring, intensified TNA warming contributes to WNPAC strengthening primarily through quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains in the upper troposphere, and the influence of equatorial wave processes weakens. c In summer, the combined effects of enhanced TNA warming and the central Pacific cooling intensify WNPAC via equatorial Rossby wave dynamics and the strengthening of easterlies over the tropical western Pacific, driven by the enhanced SST gradient between the Indo-Pacific warm pool and the central-western Pacific.Full size imageTropical ocean basins are physically interconnected through large-scale atmospheric circulation, and such inter-basin interactions—via the Walker circulation or subtropical teleconnections—can modulate WNPAC response. To assess whether these interactions bias our attribution, we conducted sensitivity tests by additionally removing SST anomalies from the other two basins when isolating each ocean’s effect. While this may dampen some coupled signals, the influential patterns remained largely consistent. This suggests that although inter-basin coupling exists and may modulate the total response, the dominant pathways and relative contributions of each ocean remain physically robust and are not artifacts of the regression setup.Our study suggests that warming over the Indian Ocean contributes only modestly to the intensification of WNPAC. Although partial regression patterns reveal a relatively intensified WNPAC and anomalous easterlies in summer (Fig. 7c) under intensified TIO warming (Fig. 2i), the response appears to be primarily driven by suppressed convection over the western Pacific, as well as the weak convection response in the northern Indian Ocean. This is consistent with He et al.40, who also emphasized the importance of the zonal SST gradient between the TIO and Pacific, but highlighted that the gradient becomes increasingly shaped by stronger and more consistent Pacific SST cooling under warming scenarios. Furthermore, both studies identify a weakened sensitivity of WNPAC to TIO SST anomalies, largely due to enhanced atmospheric stability and shallower vertical motion over TIO35,40,48, which suppresses the generation of warm Kelvin waves. This weakened response not only reduces the direct impact of TIO warming but also limits the TIO’s contribution to strengthening the zonal SST gradient, ultimately leading to a lower relative contribution from the Indian Ocean to WNPAC intensification under global warming. These findings highlight the need for further quantitative investigation into the Indian Ocean’s independent mechanistic role under global warming, particularly its coupling with regional atmospheric dynamics.MethodsReanalysis and CMIP6 dataIn this study, monthly SST data are sourced from the Extended Reconstructed Sea Surface Temperature version 5 (ERSSTv5)49 at a horizontal resolution of \(2^\circ \,\times \,2^\circ\). Monthly sea level pressure (SLP) data are obtained from the European Center for Medium-Range Weather Forecasting Reanalysis version 5 (ERA5)50 at a spatial resolution of 0.25° × 0.25°.To estimate the future changes in WNPAC, monthly outputs from 43 CMIP6 models are analyzed for the period 1900-2099 (Supplementary Table 1). The historical simulations up to 2014 are conducted under historical scenario forcing, followed by future projections under the Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5–8.5 (SSP585) high-emission scenario, representing a warming climate. To ensure consistency, monthly anomaly variables—including SLP, precipitation (Precip), geopotential height (GPH), SST, tropospheric temperature (TT), and vertical (W) and horizontal (U, V) winds—are derived by referencing the climatological mean of 1900–1999, with the linear trend removed. All variables are regridded to a 1° × 1° resolution. Seasonal data are obtained by averaging the monthly values for boreal winter (December–February, DJF), spring (March–May, MAM), and summer (June–August, JJA). Changes in WNPAC are evaluated by comparing the period 1900–2014, which represents the historical state, and 2015–2099, which represents the future state. Additionally, a comparison between 1900–1999 and 2000-2099 is conducted; however, the key findings of this study remain unchanged (not shown).Definition of indicesTo quantify the intensity of WNPAC, we compute the WNPAC index as SLP anomalies over the WNP region (10° N–30° N, 120° E–160° E)22,51. Building upon prior research19,52, SST indices for the three tropical oceans are established based on the regions exerting the greatest impact on WNPAC: CEP (10° S–10° N, 180°–90° W) for the Pacific Ocean, TIO (20° S–20° N, 40° E–100° E) for the Indian Ocean and TNA (0°–20° N, 80° W–20° W) for the Atlantic Ocean (Supplementary Fig. 1). SST anomalies exert seasonally varying influences on WNPAC, with peak impacts observed for winter SST anomalies in the CEP region in winter and subsequent spring/summer WNPAC variability, and spring/summer SST anomalies in the TIO and TNA regions on simultaneous-season WNPAC dynamics (Supplementary Fig. 4d–f). All regressed indices are standardized to enhance comparability and stability by eliminating unit dependence.Furthermore, the variability of WNPAC and the three oceans’ indices is quantified using a 31-year moving standard deviation of each index. The frequency of WNPAC events is defined as the number of occurrences where the WNPAC index exceeds 0.75 standard deviations within the running window, while its amplitude is derived from the mean WNPAC index of these events53.To quantify the intensity of processes by which three tropical oceans contribute to WNPAC, indices for equatorial waves and the quasi-stationary Rossby wave train are defined. The intensity of the equatorial Rossby wave is measured by the magnitude of the negative area-averaged precipitation anomaly over the tropical western Pacific (5°N–25°N, 130°E–180°E), where a stronger negative anomaly reflects enhanced anticyclonic Rossby wave activity contributing to WNPAC. Kelvin wave index is defined as the magnitude of the negative (easterly) mean zonal wind anomaly over the equatorial western Pacific (0°–5°N, 120°E–160°E). Similarly, the strength of anomalous easterlies over the WNP region is measured by the magnitude of the negative mean zonal wind anomaly over the western Pacific (0°–15°N, 120°E–160°E). The intensity of the quasi-stationary Rossby wave train, which is triggered by tropical North Atlantic warming and propagates to the WNP, is quantified by the 200 hPa GPH anomalies over key circulation anomaly regions along the wave path (as shown in Fig. 5g), defining as: -GPH(30°N–45°N,80°W–30°W) + GPH(50°N–65°N,60°W–10°W) -GPH(45°N–60°N,10°E–60°E) + GPH(40°N–55°N,70°E–120°E) -GPH(25°N–40°N,110°E–160°E).Bootstrap estimation of inter-model uncertaintyTo estimate the inter-model spread of the multi-model ensemble for each year, we apply a bootstrap resampling procedure to the annual ensemble of model mean54. For each year, 10,000 bootstrap samples are generated by resampling 43 model ensembles with replacement. The standard deviation is computed for each resample, and the mean of the 10,000 standard deviations is used as the uncertainty estimate for that year. This approach provides a robust estimate of ensemble variability and is used to construct the uncertainty shading in Fig. 1.Contribution indices of three tropical oceans to WNPACThe relative contributions of the three tropical oceans to WNPAC are assessed via the explained variance (EV) of regions exerting the strongest influence on WNPAC, identical to those used in calculating the three oceans’ SST indices. The explained variance is determined as the regional mean of squared correlation coefficients between the SST anomalies and WNPAC index, formulated as:$$\begin{array}{c}{EV}=\frac{1}{N}{\sum }_{i=1}^{N}\left({r}_{i}^{2}\right)\end{array}$$
                    (1)
                Here, \({EV}\) represents the explained variance, \(N\) denotes the number of grid points in the defined region, \({r}_{i}\) is the Pearson correlation coefficient between SST anomalies and WNPAC index at grid point \(i\), and R-square represents the coefficient of determination. This metric quantifies the proportion of WNPAC variability attributable to SST variations at each grid point.The Pearson correlation coefficient \({r}_{i}\) at grid point \(i\) is calculated as:$$\begin{array}{c}{r}_{i}=\frac{{\sum }_{t=1}^{T}\left({SS}{T}_{i,t}-\overline{{SS}{T}_{i}}\right)\left({WNPA}{C}_{t}-\overline{{WNPAC}}\right)}{\sqrt{{\sum }_{t=1}^{T}{\left({SS}{T}_{i,t}-\overline{{SS}{T}_{i}}\right)}^{2}}\sqrt{{\sum }_{t=1}^{T}{\left({WNPA}{C}_{t}-\overline{{WNPAC}}\right)}^{2}}}\end{array}$$
                    (2)
                where \({SS}{T}_{i,t}\) represents the SST at grid point \(i\) and time \(t\), \(\overline{{SS}{T}_{i}}\) is the climatological mean SST at grid point \(i\), \({WNPA}{C}_{t}\) denotes WNPAC index at time \(t\), \(\overline{{WNPAC}}\) is the climatological mean of WNPAC index, and \(T\) corresponds to the total number of temporal observations. These formulas establish a robust statistical framework to quantify the contributions of SST variability across the three ocean basins to WNPAC dynamics, enabling a comparative evaluation of their relative influences. The rate of increase in explained variance is calculated as the percentage rise under future forcing relative to historical forcing.Liang–Kleeman information flowThe Liang–Kleeman information flow framework is an information-theoretic approach that measures the causal influence between two time series43,44. Unlike correlation, which is symmetric, information flow is directional, thereby allowing identification of driver–response relationships. The directionality and strength of causality from SST (X₂) to WNPAC (X₁) is estimated under a linear model as:$${T}_{2\to 1}=\frac{{C}_{11}{C}_{12}{C}_{2,{\rm{d}}1}-{C}_{12}^{2}{C}_{1,{\rm{d}}1}}{{C}_{11}^{2}{C}_{22}-{C}_{11}{C}_{12}^{2}}$$
                    (3)
                where\(\,{C}_{{ij}}\) is the sample covariance between \({X}_{i}\) and \({X}_{j}\), and \({C}_{i,{dj}}\) is the covariance between \({X}_{i}\) and the time derivative of \({X}_{j}\). A significant positive \({T}_{2\to 1}\) indicates a causal influence from SST to WNPAC.Lead–lag correlation analysisLead–lag correlation analysis was conducted between the dominant SST modes of the tropical Pacific, Indian, and Atlantic Oceans and WNPAC index. Correlation coefficients were calculated with SST anomalies leading or lagging the WNPAC index by up to 9 months. This approach identifies the season of peak influence for each basin on WNPAC variability and provides the physical basis for the seasonal pairing adopted in the EV and regression analyses.Wave activity flux (WAF) calculationThe WAF shown in Fig. 5 is calculated based on the formula of Takaya and Nakamura55, which diagnoses the horizontal propagation of quasi-stationary Rossby waves. The WAF is computed at 200 hPa using monthly mean fields of zonal wind u, meridional wind v, and geopotential height \(\Phi\) from the CMIP6 model outputs. Eddy components are defined as deviations from the zonal mean.The horizontal components of the WAF vector are given by:$$\begin{array}{lll}\vec{{W}_{h}}&=&\frac{pcos\varphi }{2\left|\vec{{U}_{c}}\right|}\left(\frac{{U}_{c}}{{a}^{2}{\cos }^{2}\varphi }\right.\left[{\left(\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \lambda }\right)}^{2}-{\psi }^{{\prime} }\frac{{\partial }^{2}{\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial {\lambda }^{2}}\right]\\&&+\,\frac{{V}_{c}}{{a}^{2}\cos \varphi }\left[\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \lambda }\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \varphi }-{\psi }^{{\prime} }\frac{{\partial }^{2}{\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \lambda \partial \varphi }\right]\frac{{U}_{c}}{{a}^{2}\cos \varphi }\left[\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \lambda }\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \varphi }-{\psi }^{{\prime} }\frac{{\partial }^{2}{\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \lambda \partial \varphi }\right]\\&&+\,\left.\frac{{V}_{c}}{{a}^{2}}\left[{\left(\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \varphi }\right)}^{2}-{\psi }^{{\prime} }\frac{{\partial }^{2}{\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial {\varphi }^{2}}\right]\right)\end{array}$$
                    (4)
                where \(\psi {\prime}\) is the perturbation stream function, derived from the ratio of geopotential anomaly \(\Phi {\rm{\mbox{'}}}\) to the planetary vorticity \(f\), \({U}_{c}\) and \({V}_{c}\) are the climatological zonal and meridional winds, \(a\) is the Earth’s radius, \(\lambda\) and \(\varphi\) are longitude and latitude, and \(p\) is the normalized atmospheric pressure. This formula allows visualization of wave energy propagation associated with anomalous circulation.Partial regression analysisThe partial regression model is a statistical method used to isolate the relationship between independent and dependent variables by removing the influence of a control variable56. In this study, signals from other ocean basins may obscure the individual effects of the target basin. To disentangle these influences, a partial linear regression analysis is applied:$$\begin{array}{c}Y=\alpha \times {I}_{A}+r.{Y}_{-A}\end{array}$$
                    (5)
                $$\begin{array}{c}r.{Y}_{-A}=\gamma \times {\rm{I}}+r.{Y}_{-I-A}\end{array}$$
                    (6)
                Here, \(Y\) denotes the target climate variable (e.g., precipitation, SLP, SST), \(I\) represents the SST indices of the target oceans (CEP, TIO, TNA indices), and \({I}_{A}\) represents the controlling NINO3.4 index to be removed. Equation (5) removes the direct influence of \({I}_{A}\) from \(Y\), yielding the residual \(r.{Y}_{-A}\); and Eq. (6) regresses \(r.{Y}_{-A}\) onto \(I\), thus quantifying the independent relationship between \(Y\) and \(I\) after removing the effect of ENSO. The coefficients \({\rm{\alpha }}\) quantify the direct influence of ENSO, while \({\rm{\gamma }}\) characterizes the regression coefficients between \(Y\) and \(I\) after the removal of the ENSO effect, reflecting the relatively independent association between the climate variable and each ocean index.In this analysis, the NINO3.4 index is removed using its DJF-mean value to account for ENSO’s mature-phase influence and its delayed impacts on subsequent seasons. In subsequent regressions, the Pacific (CEP) index is represented by its DJF value to reflect the dominant wintertime ENSO forcing, while TIO and TNA indices are used in their concurrent seasons based on their seasonally confined influence (Supplementary Fig. 4d–f).

Data availability
              
              The CMIP6 dataset is accessible via the ESGF portal at https://esgf-data.dkrz.de/search/cmip6-dkrz/. The NOAA ERSST-v5 dataset can be obtained from https://downloads.psl.noaa.gov/Datasets/noaa.ersst.v5/. ERA5 reanalysis data are available at https://doi.org/10.24381/cds.f17050d7. All data supporting the findings of this study are provided within the article and its supplementary materials.

items.title: Le “regole ambientali” per eventi sostenibili e carbon neutral: la PCR 962
items.description: Eventi a basso impatto climatico E’ stato rilasciato un importante documento che definisce le Regole di Categoria di Prodotto (PCR) per il calco
items.body:
Le “regole ambientali” per eventi sostenibili e carbon neutral: la PCR 962

Approfondimenti

condividi:

Eventi a basso impatto climatico

E' stato rilasciato un importante documento che definisce le Regole di Categoria di Prodotto (PCR) per il calcolo dell'impatto climatico degli eventi ("Carbon Footprint", sinteticamente "CF"), la valutazione primaria per poi attuare soluzioni di riduzione e compensazione delle emissioni di gas serra di un evento pubblico.

In sostanza, la PCR stabilisce cosa considerare nel processo di calcolo della Carbon Footprint degli eventi, che deve essere realizzarsi secondo un approccio tecnico di LCA secondo le indicazioni dello standard ISO 14067.

Le specifiche tecniche che emergono dalla PCR:

Prodotto Coperto: si tratta dell'organizzazione e gestione di eventi di qualsiasi dimensione, portata e durata, organizzati da enti pubblici o Aziende private. La PCR considera eventi sportivi, culturali, sociali, aziendali, networking, fundraising, festival, eventi per la comunità, concerti e spettacoli dal vivo.

Esclusione: sono esclusi gli eventi online.

Codice UN CPC: 962 ("Servizi di spettacolo e altri servizi di intrattenimento dal vivo, presentazione e promozione di eventi").

Unità Funzionale: 1 partecipante (i risultati sono espressi in kgCO2 equivalenti per singola persona).

Durata di Validità: dal 14 febbraio 2023 al 13 febbraio 2028.

Quali dati e quali regole di calcolo sono necessari per il calcolo della CF?

Il CFP segue un approccio "cradle to grave" e si divide in tre fasi: pre-evento, evento e post-evento.

1. Pre-evento (UPSTREAM): comprende progettazione (riunioni), pianificazione e organizzazione (pubblicità e sviluppo). I processi oggetto di valutazione comprendono la produzione di cibo/bevande/gadget, materiali promozionali/comunicazione, strutture temporanee monouso, consumo di energia, alloggio e trasporto per le riunioni organizzative.

2. Evento (CORE): questa fase include le voci di allestimento/preparazione, evento principale, eventi funzionali e intrattenimento collaterale (cibo e bevande). I processi oggetto di valutazione comprendono il trasporto di merci/strutture (solo andata), il trasporto (andata e ritorno) e l'alloggio di staff, partecipanti, accompagnatori e media, consumo di energia e fughe di gas refrigeranti.

3. Post-evento (DOWNSTREAM): si contabilizza il ritorno delle persone e smontaggio dell'evento. I processi oggetto di valutazione comprendono il trasporto di merci/strutture (solo ritorno), smontaggio, consumo di energia per riunioni post-evento significative, e trattamento/trasporto dei rifiuti generati.

Dati Specifici: devono essere quanto più possibile utilizzati i dati primari (raccolti in loco). I dati secondati possono essere usati se non sono disponibili dati specifici, ma devono essere rappresentativi.

Categorie di Impatto (CFP): lo studio è focalizzato sul Potenziale di Riscaldamento Globale (GWP), ovverossia la Carbon Footprint dell'evento.

Il contributo di Rete Clima agli eventi sostenibili e carbon neutral

Attraverso gli eventi le Aziende presentano se stesse, la propria vision, i propri valori, la propria attenzione alla sostenibilità.

Il Protocollo MakEGreen (Make your Event Green) di Rete Clima nasce per limitare l'impronta ambientale degli eventi tramite loro eco-progettazione e per azzerarne l’impatto climatico (carbon neutrality) tramite calcolo e gestione della loro carbon footprint.

Si tratta di un iter integrato rispetto a diversi standard del mondo ISO (quali ISO 20121 + ISO 14067) perchè l'evento sia occasione di concreta azione ambientale e sia strumento di responsabilità, di comunicazione e di "ingaggio green" dei propri stakeholder.

NOTA: i due standard ISO sopraccitati possono essere utilizzati anche singolarmente, Rete Clima propone anche una proposta tecnica basata anche solo sull'uno o sull'altro standard.

Per maggiori informazioni consulta questa pagina web su nostro sito e chiedici informazioni cliccando sul banner a seguito.

Richiedi maggiori informazioni al nostro team

items.title: IKEA insieme a WWF Italia per proteggere l’Orso bruno marsicano
items.description:
IKEA e WWF Italia lanciano una collaborazione per garantire un futuro all'Orso bruno marsicano, simbolo del nostro patrimonio
The post IKEA insieme a
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Insieme per salvare un simbolo del patrimonio ambientale italiano. IKEA e WWF Italia lanciano una collaborazione per garantire un futuro all’Orso bruno marsicano. IKEA supporta infatti il progetto del WWF Italia che punta a tutelare questo animale. Dal 1 al 30 novembre 2025, acquistando qualsiasi peluche IKEA, 1 euro sarà destinato al progetto per tutelare questo prezioso simbolo della fauna italiana. Un simbolo in pericolo L’Orso bruno marsicano è una sottospecie endemica dell’Appennino centrale e uno dei simboli del patrimonio ambientale italiano. Questa popolazione è inserita nella lista rossa IUCN tra le specie in pericolo critico di estinzione (si stima la presenza in natura di solo 50-60 esemplari). Tra le principali minacce per la sua sopravvivenza c’è la mortalità causata dall’uomo, sia illegale (bracconaggio tramite arma da fuoco, veleno o trappole), sia accidentale (tramite investimenti stradali in primis). L’uomo ha una grande responsabilità anche nella frammentazione dell’habitat di questo animale. A causarla sono le infrastrutture (strade, ferrovie) che ostacolano i naturali spostamenti degli orsi e aumentano i rischi di mortalità anche in aree idonee. La collaborazione tra IKEA e WWF Italia Per contrastare queste minacce il WWF Italia, grazie alla collaborazione con Ikea, lavora su tre fronti: mettere in sicurezza delle strade, grazie all’installazione di dissuasori visivi e acustici e al ripristino dei sottopassi per garantire passaggi sicuri per l’orso; ridurre i conflitti, grazie alla fornitura di recinzioni elettrificate per proteggere allevamenti e arnie nelle aree di presenza dell’orso; migliorare la percezione sociale dell’orso, grazie ad attività di sensibilizzazione e informazione per comunità locali e turisti che frequentano i territori dell’Appennino centrale.

items.title: Un’ibrida plug-in pensata per chi ama il piacere di guida: Alfa Romeo ripensa così la Tonale
items.description: A 5 anni dal debutto torna l’Alfa Romeo Tonale e promette di mettere la sportività davanti a tutto (anche all’efficienza…). Fra le novità anche l’ediz
items.body:
Le auto elettriche sono noiose da guidare. Bugia!

Elettrica, ibrida, accessibile: così il colosso cinese Geely porta in Italia la sua idea di mobilità sostenibile

Elettrica, ibrida, accessibile: così il colosso cinese Geely porta in Italia la sua idea di mobilità sostenibile
		
		
			Per supportare la transizione energetica dell’auto servono efficienza, accessibilità e fiducia. Oltre a un profondo senso di responsabilità ambientale e sociale: la ricetta di Geely Italia.
		
		
			 Auto
			27 settembre 2025
			
				di Roberto Sposini

Ai dazi Ue contro le auto elettriche la Cina risponde con ibride sempre più efficienti. L’ultimo caso la Omoda 9
		
		
			E se le misure protezionistiche imposte da Bruxelles stessero accelerando (involontariamente) lo sviluppo di modelli ibridi sempre più efficienti?  
		
		
			 Auto
			3 giugno 2025
			
				di Roberto Sposini

Un suv essenziale, leggero, ibrido e accessibile: l’esempio di Bigster
		
		
			Cresciuto in lunghezza (ma in 2 ci si può anche dormire), semplice, efficiente e leggero. Con Bigster Dacia rilancia l’ibrido accessibile. La nostra prova. 
		
		
			 Auto
			10 aprile 2025
			
				di Roberto Sposini

Piacere di guida ed efficienza, un compromesso possibile
			
			
				Il piacere di guida di un’auto sportiva non può dimenticare l’efficienza. Bmw con la serie 2 Coupé mild hybrid mostra che una “convivenza” è possibile.

Auto

20 marzo 2025

Cos’è il “super ibrido” lanciato dal marchio cinese Jaecoo
			
			
				“Il meglio dei due mondi”, ossia i vantaggi dell’ibrido plug-in uniti a quelli dell’elettrico, questo è quanto promette Jaecoo 7 Super Hybrid. Con quali esiti? La risposta nella nostra prova.

Auto

14 marzo 2025

Dfsk, perché l’auto cinese è più un’opportunità che una minaccia
			
			
				Col debutto del brand Dfsk cresce la disponibilità di auto cinesi low cost e di buona qualità, una possibile risposta all’urgenza (e al costo) della transizione ecologica dell’auto.

Auto

12 ottobre 2024

Mercato auto, a maggio le ibride superano il 40% di share
			
			
				Le ibride nel mese guadagnano 5,4 punti e superano il 40% di share. Piacciono soprattutto suv e crossover, con Nissan Quashqai sul secondo gradino del podio; cosa offre il nuovo modello.

Auto

21 giugno 2024

Bentley: “Entro il 2030 tutti i nostri modelli saranno elettrici”
			
			
				Da oltre cent’anni il principale produttore di motori a benzina 12 cilindri, Bentley entro il 2030 dirà addio ai propulsori a combustione. Obiettivo (sfidante…), “diventare leader globale nella mobilità di lusso sostenibile”.

Auto

1 giugno 2024

Auto ibride: tante le novità, ma senza incentivi le vendite rischiano la paralisi
			
			
				Gli incentivi arriveranno (forse) a maggio. Nell’attesa, il mercato delle ibride si ferma ad aprile al 3,3%. Mentre i costruttori riscoprono modelli compatti e accessibili, come la MG3.

Auto

6 maggio 2024
